pros: The Chancellor and senior leadership have a strong vision for driving this school to becoming great. The staff work hard to accommodate and execute on the vision. New faculty coming in to the university are top notch and bring promise with their research and determination.
cons: The school is transitioning from being a teaching commuter school to being a research intensive university. Currently it seams that most of the intensive research is purely superficial and used as public relations hype. There is a cadre of older faculty who are here because they don't want to work hard nor create an environment of excellence. They tend to have a strong authority on decision making which inhibits progress. The first situation I have seen where letting faculty have a voice actually is hurting the university.

review_title: Great school. Employment leave much to be desired.
pros:
• State of the art technology
• Great students
• Fantastic plan for sick and vacation days (hard to use them all)
• Very welcoming to people of all backgrounds and origins
• Relaxed work atmosphere compared to most non-edu positions
cons:
• Paying a bunch for parking every year
• Performance has little to no correlation to pay- the person who works twice as hard and stays late gets paid the same as the person who takes two hour lunches and leaves early
• There is a huge disconnect from upper management to all other departments - many groups/people are working separately towards the same goal instead of consolidating resources 
• In many departments there is no room for advancement, growth or increase in pay unless you leave your position for one in a different department which is pretty common

pros: Most people I interacted with were nice and helpful. Deadlines are generally relaxed and the culture reflects this.
cons: Nearly impossible to communicate even with my own supervisors, as it can take days to get a response to even a single email. Some of the staff (including professors) were woefully under-qualified, and all the students knew it. Everything is done by tradition, even if the practice is no longer relevant or it wastes the time of students or employees. Many of the students in the courses I assisted with were more qualified to teach than the instructor themselves, but they would never be given the opportunity because the position requires a Master's.

pros: Overall good school, with decent programs
cons: Computer science related degrees spend too much time on theory and should devote upward of 55% of curriculum on practical applications not theory. Theory has its place in academia, but it is a little disappointing leaving the school with no real skills that you can attest to. Also key classes for your major can be filled up by people who are simply taking electives which is annoying and can hinder your progression.

pros: As an on campus employer, they are flexible with your class schedule.  There aren't many times when you're asked to come in on your day off.
cons: Pretty much everything.  Management is tone-deaf.  They know little about how to manage human beings.  Everyone is a commodity.  They give the employees more work--more labs to roam, more software to learn, etc., but the employees are still paid minimum wage no matter how much extra work they get stuck with.  No matter how good of a job you do with something, management will also find something wrong with it, and find a way to humiliate you about it.

review_title: ONLY USE AS A STEPPING STONE
pros: I was able to make a difference in students lives.
cons: The management and supervisors are AWFUL.  The Chief is unbelievably condescending and is a dictator.  If you request night or day shift, they will literally give you the opposite (seen this on many occasions).  The sergeants (especially the female ones) are bullies, will talk about officers behind their backs and they do not care about you... I have seen 7 officers in a row be pushed out by being treated so poorly bc you are just another number to them.  All of the cars are literally falling apart, and break down daily.  You will have to come in on your days off constantly for training or MANDATORY overtime multiple times a month... during football season, you will work every single game.

pros: Working at HRL, I got a huge variety of experience. Every day held something new. The scheduling for student workers was extremely flexible.
cons: The variance of work from day to day caused some bad habits in the workforce. Some days would be very easy and relaxed, and some days would be difficult. This is all well and good, but some of the employees got a bit too used to the easy days. When the hard times came, a lot of people forgot that they were being paid to work.

pros: One of the best parts of the position is the flexibility of scheduling which is important as a student. Work flow varies but when it's busy the team is good at coming together to get it done. review_title: Job quality likely depends highly on the program/department
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Charlotte, MI
pros:
I am a PhD student in a great program here at UNCC. Our stipends are decent. The professors generally publish often and most of them are good about putting students as authors. The culture is very welcoming and collaborative. I feel quite comfortable and chummy with the members of my program.

Student health care is good.

Living in Charlotte is awesome. There's great weather. You have everything you could want from a city, for the most part. The light rail takes you most places you'd need. I've been able to go without a car for several years because of the light rail. You have access to awesome mountains and the beach. It's a bit of a drive, but it's great for short weekend trips.
cons:
THE FEES! Even if you get a full funding for a PhD, you will still have to pay the fees. Mine cost about $1300 per semester. They literally cannot go higher because they are at the "maximum," whatever that means. The fees aren't different for grad students either. So grad students pay for undergrad events and resources that we will never use. I have no idea what all the fees go towards. Some of it goes to hold these stupid grad school events (e.g., ice cream social, food truck). I think it also goes to writing help for your diss and other professional development stuff like that. WHO CARES! Get rid of the piddly ice cream socials. Get rid of non-discipline specific professional help. The profs should be responsible for career and writing advice that is specific to your discipline. Stop making us pay over $300 per month towards these BS fees. 

My stipend is one of the higher ones at UNCC. A living wage in Charlotte for no kids is $27k. With the fees, I make some $23k. I've heard some god awful numbers like $13k before... They said they were changing that before the virus to make pay better and more equitable, but I haven't heard anything. They also said they were getting rid of the fees. But again... now higher ed is freaking out re: virus. So that's probably not a concern to anyone any more. Better hope you don't have a major expense come up for the five years you're here.
